head.title: Black Knights' Troubles Grow in Loss to Memphis

hedline.hl1: Black Knights' Troubles Grow in Loss to Memphis

block.p: Four straight losses at the end of last college football season cost Bob Sutton his coaching job at Army. Sutton's firing also marked the end of the run-oriented wishbone offense that Army had used for 16 years.

Although the new head coach, Todd Berry, has instituted a wide-open passing offense, the result has not changed. Army lost, 26-16, to Memphis in a Conference USA game before a crowd of 38,375 at Michie Stadium. With the loss, the Black Knights matched their season-ending streak of four in 1999.

Four straight losses at the end of last college football season cost Bob Sutton his coaching job at Army. Sutton's firing also marked the end of the run-oriented wishbone offense that Army had used for 16 years.

Although the new head coach, Todd Berry, has instituted a wide-open passing offense, the result has not changed. Army lost, 26-16, to Memphis in a Conference USA game before a crowd of 38,375 at Michie Stadium. With the loss, the Black Knights matched their season-ending streak of four in 1999.

With Memphis leading in the fourth quarter, 20-14, quarterback Curtis Zervic's pass into the end zone was picked off in the left corner by defensive back Idrees Bashir, who ran the ball back 105 yards for a touchdown with 3 minutes 49 seconds left in the game.
Not only was it the longest pass interception run back in the 76-year history of Michie Stadium, but it also sealed Memphis's third victory in four games.

That put a damper on an otherwise superb performance by Zervic, a third-string quarterback who a year ago was the manager of the Army men's lacrosse team after quitting the football team after his freshman year.

Zervic entered today's game after quarterback Joe Gerena injured his right shoulder. The team's first-string quarterback, Chad Jenkins, has been sidelined since injuring an ankle against Boston College two weeks ago. Zervic completed 28 passes for 246 yards to tie a record set by Leamon Hall in 1976. He had four completions on Army's ill-fated drive. Army was on the Memphis 14-yard line when Bashir ended the Black Knights' hopes with his interception.

''I thought I had Bryan Bowdish open when I threw the pass, but the safety made a great play,'' said Zervic, who also threw two other interceptions while connecting on 28 of 38 passes. ''Maybe I should have thrown the ball a bit shorter than I did.''
That drive was just one of Army's many missed opportunities.
Memphis led at halftime, 14-7, because the Black Knights did not score on two goal-line situations.

Memphis tailback Sugar Sanders opened the scoring by sprinting 62 yards for a touchdown on the Tigers' first possession. Army, on its third possession, drove from its 19-yard line to the Tigers' 2. But the Black Knights came away empty when Brendan Mullen's 24-yard field-goal attempt sailed wide to the left.
Army then squandered another scoring opportunity when, on the ensuing Memphis possession, Randy Mitchell blocked the punt by Ben Graves and Anthony Miller recovered the ball at the Tigers' 30.
With Zervic connecting on four straight passes, the Black Knights advanced to the Memphis 1. Zervic was stopped for no gain on a quarterback sneak on fourth down.

Army finally tied the score, 7-7, when the 5-foot-7-inch Omari Thompson, who is used as a wide receiver, running back and kick-return specialist, took a punt at the Army 28-yard line and raced 72 yards down the left sideline just under six minutes into the third quarter.

But Memphis soon regained the lead. Aided by a 15-yard roughing-the-passer penalty, Memphis followed with a 15-play, 78-yard drive that consumed almost seven minutes and ended with a 1-yard touchdown run by fullback Darche Epting with 3:03 left in the half.

''We made too many mistakes today, and didn't play up to our capabilities,'' Berry said of Army, which duplicated a feat of the 1973 team. That group lost its first four games and dropped all 10 games it played that season. The eight-game losing streak is the longest that Army has endured since the 1975 team lost its final nine games after winning its first two.
